park.fullName: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument
park.description: A monument not only of stone and mortar but of human determination and endurance, the Castillo de San Marcos symbolizes the clash between cultures which ultimately resulted in our uniquely unified nation. Still resonant with the struggles of an earlier time, these original walls provide tangible evidence of America’s grim but remarkable history.

entranceFees.description: Individual admission for persons 16 years of age or older.
entranceFees.title: Castillo Entrance Fee - Per Person - Adult

entranceFees.description: Individual admission for person age 15 and younger
entranceFees.title: Castillo Entrance Fee - Per Person - Child

entrancePasses.description: One year admission pass for the card holder and up to three additional adults.
entrancePasses.title: Castillo Annual Pass

park.directionsInfo: On State Route A1A overlooking Matanzas Bay in the heart of the historic district of Saint Augustine, the Castillo is approximately a five mile drive from Interstate 95.

operatingHours.description: Due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the Castillo de San Marcos is closed to the public. We do not currently have a reopening date scheduled. Our website and social media will be updated with any changes.  Normally, the Castillo is open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Thanksgiving and Christmas.
operatingHours.name: COVID-19 Closure

images.title: Castillo Drawbridge
images.altText: Drawbridge entrance to the Castillo de San Marcos
images.caption: Crossing a dry moat, this drawbridge was the only way into the Castillo.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Hot Shot Furnace
images.caption: This furnace, in the water battery on the east side of the Castillo, heated cannonballs red hot to be fired at wooden vessels.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Cannon
images.altText: Four black iron cannon mounted on carriages line the walls of the Castillo.
images.caption: The Castillo features both iron and bronze cannon and mortar from the period.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Cannon Firing
images.altText: Re-enactors of the first Spanish period cover their ears while firing a cannon.
images.caption: Cannon firing demonstrations are scheduled five times a day every Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Aerial View
images.altText: Aerial view of the Castillo and the city of St. Augustine
images.caption: the Castillo commands the northern edge of the heart of downtown St. Augsutine.

park.weatherInfo: St. Augustine has a semi-tropical climate with over 300 days of sunshine each year. Summers (May-September) are hot, bright, and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F. Spring (March-mid-May) and Autumn (October-late November) can be pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F. The Winter months (December-March) are usually dry. Temperatures can be cool ranging from the upper 30s through the 60sF.
park.name: Castillo de San Marcos

eatery.description: Five generations of the McClard family have been working the smoker since they opened their spot in the '20s, which is a type of nepotism no one who's ever eaten their ribs or chicken is complaining about. One of the most popular dishes is the tamale spread, a vast pile of food that includes tamales covered in Fritos, beans, chopped meat, onions, and cheese -- it was initially thrown together in the early '70s to help one of the dishwashers sober up, but eventually caught on with the customers. It's uniquely McClard's and uniquely Arkansas.

attraction.name: Cabazon Dinosaurs
attraction.description: In the middle of nowhere, California, stand the Cabazon Dinosaurs. There are two dinosaurs, and they are glorious — not to mention highly photographed by tourists on their way to vacation in Palm Springs. These dinosaurs are also known for their appearance in Pee Wee’s Big Adventure. The long-necked dinosaur also houses stairs and a kitschy toy shop inside its body.

park.description: The Augusta Canal helped usher the Industrial Revolution into the American South. Built in 1845 as a source of power, water, and transportation, the canal today is the only fully intact American industrial canal in continuous operation. By 1847 the first mills opened, followed by the massive Civil War era Confederate Powder Works and many more industries in the later decades of the 19th century.

entranceFees.description: While there is no cost to the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area, there are fees for the Discovery Center and Canal Boat Tours.
entranceFees.title: Free Entry

park.directionsInfo: To Augusta Canal Discovery Center (1450 Greene Street, Augusta, GA 30901): From I-20 Exit 200, turn left onto GA-104/Riverwatch Parkway (signs for Downtown Augusta). In approximately 4.5 miles, use the right lane to take the ramp to Downtown Augusta/Medical District. Continue straight onto Greene Street. Continue for approximately 0.4 miles. Enterprise Mill and the Discovery Center will be on your right.

images.title: Petersburg Boat
images.altText: Petersburg Boat passes Sibley Mill and the chimney of Confederate States Powder Works along the Augu
images.caption: Petersburg Boat passes Sibley Mill and the chimney of Confederate States Powder Works along the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area

park.weatherInfo: The weather varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov for forecast information.
park.name: Augusta Canal

eatery.description: There are older restaurants, and places with wackier backstories (House Without a Key was in the first Charlie Chan novel!), but -- for nearly 40 years -- everyone knows Hy's. The classic steakhouse is known for cooking its meats over native kiawe wood, so you can't really go wrong trying the roast rack of lamb seared over the hot charcoal, paired up with a Caesar prepared tableside. It may not have been in a book, but pretty soon these guys will be writing their own.

attraction.name: White House Replica
attraction.description: Want to see the White House without having to go to D.C.? Consider traveling to Atlanta, where they have a replica three-quarters the size! The mini White House used to offer tours of its replica of the Oval Office and the Lincoln bedroom, but now it’s a private home.

park.description: Little River is unique because it flows for most of its length atop Lookout Mountain in northeast Alabama. Forested uplands, waterfalls, canyon rims and bluffs, pools, boulders, and sandstone cliffs offer settings for a variety of recreational activities. Natural resources and cultural heritage come together to tell the story of the Preserve, a special place in the Southern Appalachians.

entranceFees.description:
Located near Cedar Bluff, Alabama, the Canyon Mouth Park area features amenities including a paved parking lot, restrooms with sinks and flush toilets, picnic tables, grills, lots of shade, close to the water, and a brand new playground.

FEES ARE CURRENTLY SUSPENDED

A seven-day pass costs $15 and an annual pass costs $35 and is valid for the calendar year. 

A machine is available at the entrance to Canyon Mouth Park should no park personnel be present in the booth. The machine takes cash only.
entranceFees.title: Canyon Mouth Park picnic area

entrancePasses.description:
Give the user unlimited access during operating hours during a calendar year (January - December). Located near Cedar Bluff, Alabama. Instead of paying $15 per vehicle, purchase the pass for a year for $35. Amenities included paved parking lot, restrooms, picnic tables, grills, lots of shade, close to the water, and a playground. 

America the Beautiful passes are also valid at Canyon Mouth Park and will allow access using the fee machine or when park staff are present at the booth.
entrancePasses.title: Canyon Mouth Annual Pass

park.directionsInfo: GPS Address: 472 AL Hwy 35, Fort Payne, AL 35967. Our address was updated by 911 and some GPS units will send you to an incorrect address. Please use this address for GPS units.

operatingHours.description: The main park is open during daylight hours every day including holidays.
operatingHours.name: Little River Canyon National Preserve

operatingHours.description:
Summer Hours - Open Daily from 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM (CST)
Fall/Spring Hours - Open Daily from 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM (CST) - begins March 8, 2020 
Winter Hours - Open Daily from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM (CST)
operatingHours.name: Canyon Mouth Park

park.weatherInfo: The weather in Fort Payne, Alabama is mild. The average temperature in the winter is in the 20's. The average summer temperature is in the high 80's. We receive about 55 inches of rain each year. Snowfall varies, but only lasts a few days per event.
park.name: Little River Canyon

eatery.description: The Colorado dining scene has come a long way since the Buckhorn Exchange opened. There's practically a brewery and a buzzed-about restaurant on every street corner in Denver these days. But the Buckhorn Exchange is a glimpse into what Colorado restaurants used to be famous for -- giant portions of steak that will feed you, your friends, and your friends' friends. Beyond the steak, there's also the opportunity to eat practically every animal that was on Noah's ark. And eating here puts you in good company, as Teddy Roosevelt and Eisenhower both dined here.

attraction.name: Cabazon Dinosaurs
attraction.description: In the middle of nowhere, California, stand the Cabazon Dinosaurs. There are two dinosaurs, and they are glorious — not to mention highly photographed by tourists on their way to vacation in Palm Springs. These dinosaurs are also known for their appearance in Pee Wee’s Big Adventure. The long-necked dinosaur also houses stairs and a kitschy toy shop inside its body.
